  761. I really wanted to be able to rate this product 5 stars. The soap is wonderfully refreshing, and it is something I look forward to smelling every morning. The mug is sturdy and ergonomic, and makes building high-quality lather a breeze. The stand is stylish, yet unobtrusive, perfectly showcasing my shaving implements. As others have mentioned, however, the brush is the achilles heal of this shave set. Thankfully, I already had a Badger Brush from an Art of Shaving set I received as a gift a few years back. The sad thing is, within 2 days of use, the Van Der Hagen brush lost more hairs than my old brush had in 2 years. Not to mention that it was already lacking some heft to begin with.<br /><br />At any rate, if you already have a quality brush or don't mind purchasing one on the side, then I fully recommend this set. To those looking for a complete set, however, you may want to look elsewhere.
  762. Im 5 shaves into my de razor journey and this was a great first purchase. Soap smells good and lathers very well. I was able to get good lather first time. I did look up some videos on YouTube. I would recommend to any noob. Might not be for a seasoned vet but I would not know.
  763. Using this kit is a night-and-day difference from using aerosol shave cream. Includes a soft, high quality badger hair brush that lathers quickly and hasn't shed too badly so far in three weeks of daily use. Top quality kits may run upwards of $100; this is a fine alternative for the money.
  764. I love the dish and the soap, the brush is nice but way too many hairs started falling out, so I ordered a new one. Overall this is a great deal even if its just for the stand, soap and dish. I only gave it 4 stars because of the brush, but I do love this set.
  765. The mug is of high quality, and the stand is very useful. The soap lathers up nice, and gives a clean feeling after the shave. However, the brush, when I first got it, and even after washing it multiple times, and using it multiple times, it still has a very offensive odor. The odor is pervasive, as well. The first day I had it, while it was drying out, you could smell it when you entered the room. I live in a dorm room with one other person, and you can see where this would be a problem. Borax may help, it's next on the list of things to try.<br /><br />For $32, I'd probably buy this again, despite the complaint about the brush. The combination of items alone make it worth it. Caveat Emptor, however, be ready to deodorize the brush when you get it. Others report a much milder smelling brush than mine, maybe I got the bad one out of the bunch.
  766. I received this shave kit with a broken stand which was obviously broken at the factory during packaging. These things can happen. What annoyed me was the total lack of any customer service at Van Dear Hagens. They provided an email address which didn't accept my email! I crossed this my company off my buy from list!
  767. This is a very nice set, not cheaply made. My husband loves his. The bowl is a very generous size, we are very pleased!!!!
  768. At first my boyfriend hated this set. But now he loves the brush and the cup.<br /><br />Here's why...I was really excited to give this to him for Valentines but the set was incomplete. It was missing the soap and the soap holder. Also, as if that wasn't bad enough, the brush smelled horrible once you got it wet. My boyfriend described the smell as \\"badger fear pee\\". NOT something he wanted to use on his face. Also, the stand is super cheap and barely stands up with the brush on it.<br /><br />BUT...this set has kinda grown on him. He washed the brush out numerous times and now, over a year later...he LOVES this brush and uses it every time he shaves. (He says it helps make the hairs stand up more and gives a much nicer shave.) He also really likes the cup and says it feels comfortable in his hand. Since we never got the soap, he uses a Dr. Bronners soap instead. And the stand is cheap and is sitting in drawer now. I bought him a nice chrome stand instead. (which I should add...was difficult to find. A lot of the nice metal stand out there do not fit the brush that comes with this set)
  769. This is a good inexpensive shave set. I still use the kit today, the brush is still full of bristles and soft. I definitely would recommend buying.
  770. This shave set is nearly perfect! The mug is worth the cost of the set by itself. The soap smells great and is really easy to lather. The stand is great for storing one safety razor and one brush of your choice (will fit most brushes). However, the brush is the weakest link. It sheds like crazy, and is not very well constructed. Overall: great products, great value, but you may want to add a better badger brush to your order. I'd recommend Omega.
  771. Excellent first set. Great mug and excellent brush. Haven't used soap yet, still finishing one I had open. Really like the stand.
  772. This kit is great and the shave soap that comes with it is very effective and smells good. If you currently use store bought gells and creams you're gonna notice a huge difference. I am an every day shaver and one soap bar lasted me from December to now (March) and it still has a couple weeks of life left. The best part though is the beaver hair: it feels amazing when brushing on your face. It is quite the experience!
  773. Perfect. Everything I wanted and more.

  776. The soap is great, and the mug is very convenient.<br />The brush is excellent.<br />The stand, on the other hand, is very clumsy.<br />A standard safety razor (an old Gillette, in my case) does not fit in the slot comfortably.<br />The razor is not securely kept in the stand without turning it, and turning it interferes with the brush when in the stand.<br />I would recommend a re-design of the acrylic stand.
  777. I ordered this kit as part of my experiment with double-edged razor shaving, which was designed to help (I hoped) eliminate some persistently recurring ingrown hairs. The soap is fine and I have no complaints about the dish it sits in. I don't like the plastic stand - I've knocked it over a couple times and will be ordering another. I also cannot recommend the badger hair brush. The strong smell was still present after a month or so of use, and I replaced the brush with a smaller one that doesn't smell as much or shed as much. If you have a limited budget, this set works as a starter kit. However, I wouldn't recommend it to someone who wants to pamper himself.

  779. this starter kit is an excellent value. The mug is good quality, the razor/brush stand works great, and the brush and soap work well together.<br />I may buy another, so the brush gets 48 hours to dry fully, and i'll have a matching mug to try a different soap.
  780. All the items seem to be of good quality. Considering that all of these items separately would add up to quite a bit more than what you're paying for this seems like a smart choice for someone who is starting with nothing.<br /><br />I imagine that I'll keep using the brush and holder for a few years. The soap I will replace when it runs out, probably with a different brand (only because I like to try new things).<br /><br />I am satisfied that my money was well spent and I would recommend this set to anyone who may be wondering where to start.
  781. So I've had this set for quite a while now and have decided to leave my review.<br /><br />-- The Good<br /> The Brush knot is nice and full, if a little too floppy.<br /> The Soap smells nice and it's fit is perfect for the mug.<br /> The Mug is probably the best part of the set with the windmill printed on both sides.<br /> The Stand works as it should and is a step-up from my home made wire-hanger brush stand.<br /><br />-- The Bad<br /> The brush is quite floppy and loses hair like mad. Just today over 40 hairs came out (worse than the Van Der Hagen boar brush and that's saying something!)<br /> The soap, while smelling wonderful, barely foams and goes on as thin as hand soap.<br /><br />I really wanted to like this set as my favorite cheap brush is the Van Der Hagen boar brush (once it stops losing hair every shave and you soften it up, it works wonders for a boar brush.), but to say that this brush is low quality is insulting to low quality brushes, my $10 tweezerman badger brush works better, is less floppy, and hasn't lost more than 15 hairs in its life time! This brush on the other hand, loses at least five hairs every shave. So today i decided to work out all the bad hairs I could from the knot, i got over 40 hairs to come out with little effort. Repeating the same process on my tweezerman yielded less than 4 hairs. For how long i've been using the brush it should have ceased to losing hairs at this point, and yet it still does. The soap smells decent, but when attempting to lather all I ever get is foam! Granted, I have hard water, but i've so many different soaps and creams to compare from and this is by far the thinnest, least lubricating shaving soap I own, this even includes the lowest end Van Der Hagen soaps! The only good thing to come from this whole set is the mug.<br /><br />All-in-all I'm very, very disappointed with this purchase. If you need a brush for cheap either go with the tweezerman badger hair or if you want a boar, and can deal with tons of hairs falling out of the knot, get the Van Der Hagen boar brush. What ever you do, do not waste your money on anything in this set except, maybe, the mug.
  782. For a beginner this is a great deal. For experienced shavers this is still a really good deal. The mug is heavy, feels sturdy and overall gives a nice in hand feel. The brush is good quality, but will lose a few hairs to start with, but I'm hard pressed to find brushes that don't. Keep in mind it comes witha a Soap and not a Cream. A soap will lather marginally less but glide better, so keep that in mind. I am not the biggest fan of the plastic holder, but that's because my razor is chrome and it doesn't fit well with the look. Great kit otherwise.
  783. UPDATE: since my initial review (below) I feel the need to warn those considering this item. Yes, the mug is almost worth the cost... However, the soap doesn't lather and moreover, the badger hair brush has not stopped shedding YET ( after nearly a month and a half of use)!!!<br /><br />Every shave I end up with what I call 'badger beard' since I have more badger hair on my face than of my own. This endless shedding of badger hairs ruins the shaving experience when I have to stop mid-shave and pick badger hair off my face.<br /><br />Spend your money elsewhere. I am glad to have the nice mug, but I've just ordered a cheap Tweezerman badger brush (which is reviewed favorably) and will promptly convert this 'luxury' brush into a paint brush once it arrives.<br /><br />Original review:<br />I've just started with safety and straight razor shaving recently. I thought I'd splurge on this 'lux' set so I'd get off to a good start.<br /><br />Love the mug, feels like quality. Stand is just cheap plastic (maybe acrylic?) and does the job, but is kinda unstable.<br /><br />Brush loses hairs like a shedding Shepard dog. The irony is I've gone through all this expense of getting the closest, most traditional (and economical) shave I can, but I still have long hairs on my face at the end of the shave due to this brush shedding.<br /><br />I've read other reviews and only a few mention this shedding issue. Not sure if that's because 'that's the way all badger brushes are' or if we few got the lemons of the brushes. And the soap really does not hold a lather well. I bought a couple of different brands of soap, and this one is the weakest lather.<br /><br />At any rate, i'll be looking for another brush with which to compare.<br /><br />Overall, the mug's nice, but this is no 'luxury' set. Save your money and get a more basic set elsewhere.
  784. I initially got this as a fairly inexpensive Christmas present for my boyfriend, trying to be creative and improve his life by buying a more luxurious hygiene item. He loves the smell, saying it is a very clean and manly smell. After shaving, he said he couldn't remember the last time his face felt so smooth. He says the brush really stands the hairs on his face up for a closer shave and the soap was perfect for the gliding action of the razor.<br /><br />Bear in mind, this is all with just using a regular disposable shaving razor. He now intends to purchase an old fashioned safety razor due to the large amount of people who claim it will take the shave on step further.<br /><br />The packaging was great and simple, and the apothecary cup is very handsome and a generous size. The amount of soap will last quite some time. After one use, it's difficult to see if a dent was even made in the amount of soap provided.<br /><br />Will probably buy again when the soap runs out!

  811. **the good<br /><br />1) The brush does a great job at what it is supposed to do; building a lather and putting it on your face.<br /><br />2) The stand holds the brush in the correct position for drying, and can hold any DE razor. It has a cleverly positioned dimple in case your razor has an especially long handle, so it can slouch in the razor slot instead of hanging.<br /><br />3) The soap smells great, and does a decent job. I have hard water, but this soap will still produce a serviceable lather.<br /><br />4) The bowl/mug holds the puck of soap perfectly and has a nice weight to it.<br /><br />**the not so good<br /><br />1) This brush is infamous for being a prolific shedder. You will be picking hairs out of your mug, your face, your razor, basically anything it comes in contact with. Forever.<br /><br />2) The stand is made of lightweight plastic, and has a bottom that lays flush with your sink. This causes it to slide erratically like a corvette driven by a teenager if it comes in contact with any soapy water, which is simply bollocks because it is designed to hold a shaving brush and razor.<br /><br />3) The soap has a manly, distinctive smell. I rather like it, honestly. It is, however, made with glycerine instead of tallow so it doesn't last very long.<br /><br />4) The mug is without fault. It very nearly makes this package worth it, but not quite.
  812. I got this kit as a started set when I first started DE shaving. The brush is adequate for beginners but if you like using it, you may want to upgrade at some point. The smell is funky the first time you get it wet but that goes away after a few shaves and is normal for all badger brushes. My brush had a shedding problem though, and after 6 months of using it, most shaves I would still lose a couple of bristles out of it. The mug is very nice looking and has a good weight to it. As you upgrade the pieces of this set over time, the mug will probably still be used. The soap has a pleasant scent and lathers pretty good with the brush. As i experimented with different products, I learned I preferred creams to soaps but I still occasionally use the puck that came with this set. The stand is clear plastic or acrylic and holds the brush upside down to let it dry and also has a slot to hold your razor. I would definitely recommend this set to anyone who wants to try out wet shaving without spending a lot of money to get started.

So now I use a smaller bowl instead.<br /><br />- The soap is nice, but I actually prefer VDH Premium Soap. You might end up with your own preference too.<br /><br />- The brush eventually fell apart. It was shedding a little bit each day, and then seriously one day the inside hairs just popped out. Now all that's left is an outer ring of hairs.<br /><br />- The stand is decent enough. The photos don't show, but the stand does have a slot behind the brush to hold a razor.<br /><br />The set does does look nice, though. So overall, not a bad way to try out brush shaving. It's a great starter kit for those just beginning and becoming overwhelmed with the products available for wet shaving. I used the soap once, but I tend to prefer Proraso Shaving Soap. It's really a personal preference though.
  847. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. I shave once a week so I don't get to use the brush that much, yet the hair on the brush keeps failing off and eventually the whole brush head went off, I guess they didn't use good glue, they weren't expecting anyone to put it under water. if you're to spend $24, you're better off buying a high end brush for the same amount!
  848. This is a nice throwback to early 20th Century. It is so much more fun to use than squirting out foam from aerosol cans. Yes it takes a little more time, but you do get a feeling of a good clean shave. Thinking of getting a straight edge...or not. probably cut my throat.
  849. You can get this at target for 19.99. I found this out a day after I received it. I recommend going to the nearest target and buying it there
  850. The product is just as described, looks very nice in the bathroom. For the price and for beginners I think is a very good choice.
  851. The stand is plastic, but looks pretty nice. The mug looks and feels like it's good quality. And the soap isn't my favorite, but it's not bad either. Good price for what you get.
  852. I was recommended this kit over the boar hair one due to the extra softness on the brush, the first few shaves using this brush it had a small amount of shedding that was expected, but nothing to drastic. The lather bowl is really nice and easy to hold while the shape keeps the lather from creeping up the sides. The soap I have only used once, and works well, but I prefer cream over soap personally.

  861. I was researching some beginner wet shaving products and really planned on going with a Merkur handle and badger brush. I wasn't sold on the butterfly setup either and figured I'd want a long handle. Well I came across this set in a Harmon Discount for almost the exact same price and I really couldn't avoid the instant gratification that came with this set and the matching Van Der Hagen butterfly short handle. I was apprehensive to spend $100+ on an initial setup and risk not enjoying wet shaving. This set is great to dip your toe in the water. I like the bowl well enough (it is larger than it appears), the brush is pretty junky but it gets you started... mine loses a lot of bristles and the lather isn't particularly great with it. The stand is very basic/cheap but works. It has a poorly designed spot for the razor handle as well. The soap is ok... maybe the soap lather sucks because of the brush but maybe its the soap. I plan on changing both anyhow.<br /><br />Bottom line is this is a great way to get started wet shaving just to make sure you plan on sticking with it. After all is said and done, I will likely only keep the bowl and maybe the stand. Brush will be first to go. The Van Der Hagen butterfly handle was pretty good though (sold separately). I was worried the head wouldn't secure the blade tightly but I was wrong.

The good news is that it goes away after a few uses.<br /><br />Fantastic product, and I will likely continue to use the Van Der Hagen soap once the included disc runs out.

  870. I received this as a Christmas present roughly two years ago. When I got it, it was a great set to have. The Brush worked amazingly for about a year. That is until it started shedding. It didn't shed one or two bristles now and then, it just ejected the whole center of the brush. I still use the mug and the soap has lasted quite some time, but have since gotten another brush.
  871. So this is my long term review- I have had this set since I started wet-shaving 2 years ago. This set was and is still great.<br /><br />Although the soap is long gone- I still use the brush and mug. I have seen a few reviews of the brush falling apart and don't want you to judge based on those few. As I said, I have used this brush for 2 years shaving every/every other day and had no issues at all.<br /><br />Soap was a great musk scent- something along the lines of TOBS Eaton College Scent shaving cream. Exactly what you expect a wet shave to smell like! I actually mixed my cream and this soap at first until the soap ran out. Great combination to use both.<br /><br />The bowl is great. Love the look- Pretty durable as i have dropped it once and its still intact.<br /><br />The Stand is a stand. Easy to clean and stored my Merkur and brush just fine...<br /><br />The brush is great. Middle of the road as far as soft/hard which is good because I am not sure either would be better to spread lather while picking up your whiskers.<br /><br />Tip for travel- I went to Walmart and asked for a large pill bottle. Perfect for storing the brush when it in a dopp kit.

  875. If I could just review the bowl, soap and stand separately, I would, but unfortunately the brush comes too. The bowl is surprisingly large and the soap shows very little wear even after a month's use. The stand comfortably fits a razor and a small/medium brush and looks very nice next to its black counterparts. These three items together are worth the price. The soap is very neutral, but lathers well, and the bowl is pretty hefty at a cheap price.<br /><br />The brush is unfortunately pretty terrible. In the first lather, it was shedding hairs as if I was pulling them out. The brush also turned the water an unsanitary shade of brown for reasons unknown. I owned a Muhle $30 badger hair brush before purchasing this set and it did neither of these things. I also noticed that the brush wouldn't keep its shape for any length of time after being wet, almost as if it was made of human hair. While it didn't go completely limp, it never returned to a semi-stiff position until completely dry. If this brush was sold separately, I wouldn't touch it with a 30 ft pole, but the other 3 pieces are absolutely worth it, and make up for the shoddy brush.

  881. Nah it's not. Sorry for starting this one off with a bold-faced lie. Anyways.....<br /><br />This purchase was a gift for myself from myself for being such a good guy last year. I had purchased a new shaving razor and wanted a stand for it and came across this. Taking a chance, I bought it and anxiously awaited it's arrival. Ok that's another lie. I bought it while at work on a Friday and went out all weekend charming girls and drinking alcohol. But alas, the Van Der hagen Men's Luxury Shave Set showed up and I got down to business.<br />The set is real clean looking, plastic but it does what it says on the box. The soap holder is very nice but I'm going to get a cover for it because I don't like having dust or anything on top of the soap I'm going to lather and place on my face. The brush is Badger hair, NOT boar hair which is good. I keep boar products limited to Boar's Head deli meats and so should you.<br />The soap is lasting a long time and applies very clean and works nicely. It doesn't have much of a scent which is good because you are literally going to slice it off your face with a razor blade anyways so who cares.<br />All in all, I give this 5 stars for a product that looks like it does on the box, works well, and is relatively inexpensive. I will deal with the mysterious Van Der Hagen company again in the future and I'm sure they look forward to it.
  882. For the price I don't think you can beat it. The soap doesn't lather up very much and after about a half dozen uses the brush so far is still kind of course and loosing hair (about three to four each time) which is kind of annoying. Based off of other reviews I've read there are a lot of better products out there, but if you're looking for something to just get yourself into the whole wet shaving experience like I was when I purchased this kit, then this is perfect for you without investing a lot of money. Now I have a better idea of what to look for when I upgrade! The stand that came with it works well and the brush also fits fine in the stand I already had purchased. After using the set for the past couple months now, the brush is holding up quite nicely and I'm loving it. It only looses a hair or two once in awhile however this is normal. I figured out how to make the lather and the soap is great too. As I said before I don't think you can beat the price for this fine set. Upgraded my original rating from a 3 to a 5.

  886. Recently purchased a double edge razor and figured I would be getting a bargain just getting the set. I sort of regret it at this point after having it for a few months because of the low quality. Van Der Hagen tries to give you a bit of everything for cheap and thats where the mistake lies. Its too cheap. I can simply say that the shaving brush does not hold up at all. It actually has a bad glue/seal around where the hair meets the handle and came apart after very light usage. The soap is actually decent and lathers well. It also has a pleasant smell. The soap dish is good and pretty average. I recommend skipping this set all together and just buying a quality brush/soap/dish separate. The best soap to get IMO is the Proraso Shaving Soap that comes in the white color (sensitive skin) and since I didn't feel like buying a $20 brush, I just picked one up for $1 at my local beauty supply store and it has held up just fine.

  888. The shave soap doesn't really work for me, but my neck is sensitive. My original review didn't think it would last long, however it slowed down losing hairs and now it hardly loses any. I prefer different shave soap but the cup and brush have done well. Because I often go 3+ days between shaves I sometimes need an cheap electric trimmer to shorten the hairs and minimize pulling but that might be the razor blade not the soap/brush.<br /><br />Good starter set.

  899. Yes this brush hand is made of plastic. No it does not matter unless you really really feel inadequate and chose to start wet shaving because you are a snob...   901. Almost a year since I bought this, and I can't recommend it enough for those people that want to start a more classical approach in their shaving routine. There is still a lot of soap left, and I shave at least twice a week. The black jar looks nice and minimalistic and design and color, easy to clean. The brush also looks nice: just remember to rinse all the water after shaving.
  902. Its unfortunate that the brush smells... like a badger's ass. However the performance of lathering and applying is good. Also, I have read many reviews about the brush breaking. I haven't had this problem yet, though I don't doubt the cheap quality, so I would be careful not to place too much pressure on the brush when lathering... there is no need to press the brush into the bowl, simply swirl the soap gently around the cup, taking care to add a few drops of water in as needed to build a &#34;cool whip&#34; consistency. Also, there have been a few hairs that have fallen out, but nothing unmanageable. UNDERSTAND, this is a basic, introductory set... it gets the job done and for those buying this as a gift, your intended person can always upgrade/replace any of the items for something better down the road if they stick with it.<br /><br />The soap smells great! But again, you loose that once you lather up with the brush so you don't get the added effect of attracting your wife with a clean smelling face. You face wont smell like a badger's ass either though.<br /><br />The stand is good... it has a place to hold your razor as well, however, the opening is somewhat too large for a safety razor but it gets the job done and the stand isn't an eyesore.<br /><br />The ceramic bowl is fantastic! It does well to hold heat when you submerge/fill it in hot water and then empty it to lather, which warms the lather giving you a more authentic shaving experience. The look is great too.<br /><br />The shipping of this set was very prompt... I received it two days after I placed the order... and a full day early, all with standard shipping.<br /><br />I am overall pleased with this set and would recommend it as an introduction to classic shaving.
  903. I bought this kit as a started set along with my first safety razor. The bowl and soap are quite nice, but the stand is cheap, and the brush had a smell for probably the first month before it went away.   906. Decent soap, decent brush, nice mug, and a cheap stand. Good price. Gets the job done. You'll want a stand for organizing, and to keep everything dry in the open, and most stands cost the same as this kit.
  907. This was a present for my son and he loved it. I would definately not hesitate to purchase it again.
  908. This is a good, inexpensive starter kit. There are a few things I'll mention about it, now that I've used it about 5 times:<br /><br />The brush is a solid starter knot, but it's a bit floppy. I think this is expected with a badger brush since the hairs are softer, but I've heard about brushes with stiffer knots, and I'll be looking for one in the not too distant future. The handle is plastic and feels mostly empty and the Van Der Hagen logo has already rubbed off from the hot water and general use. A dozen or so hairs have been lost from the brush, but nothing I didn't expect. I'm a little disappointed by this, but wasn't expecting too much for the price. If im still losing hairs in a few weeks, I'll probably be looking to dump this one altogether. Still, it lathers really well and quickly. Overall, it's an OK brush, but is within expectations given the price.<br /><br />I haven't used the soap yet as I've been focusing on a Proraso/c.o. Bigelow tube. It does, however smell fresh and clean, and I don't doubt it will do its job.<br /><br />As others have mentioned, the stand is surprisingly good for the fact that its plastic. It holds the brush and my Merkur 34c without any concern, and seems very stable. The arrangement of the brush and the razor in it together is slightly awkward, but this doesn't detract from its function as a stand. Over all it allows both brush and razor to air dry as expected and does it looking better than expected.<br /><br />The bowl is the shining star of this set. It feels good in the hand, looks sharp and keeps heat well. The flared top makes for easy mixing and the experience using it is just plain good. It may seem like a simple thing, but I really like the bowl. It will probably stick in rotation as my new hobby grows.<br /><br />Should you get this set? Maybe. It really is just OK, but I rated it 4 stars because it really met expectations for the price. I don't know that I'll ever use the soap, there are too many other ones out there that are more appealing to me. The brush is probably looking to be replaced sooner than later. The stand is a good starter. If you're looking to get something to get you started, this really is perfect for that. But if wet-shaving is something you're going to be doing long term, you might consider putting together your own set of different parts. In that, however, you end up with some level of analysis paralysis as you try to weigh the higher end options at just the word of others. For me, this just stopped the analysis paralysis and allowed me to jump into wet shaving, and I'm glad I did. Over time, however, I'll probably replace every item in this set, and I may not go back to them (that's already the case for the soap). If you can be more decisive about some nicer gear and you're willing to risk the money, I would jump at that.

  927. After years of using shaving cream from a can, I wanted to try the &#34;traditional&#34; style shaving cream based on my friends recommendations. Everyone I spoke to said get a badger hair brush. Also needed a bowl of some sort. Already had some shaving cream in a tube. After much searching, decided to try this set as it also included a stand for drying the brush.<br /><br />So far I have been very happy with the quality of everything in the set. The brush works well and lathers nicely, although I did have to wash it a few times to get out the musky animal scent. I quite like the bowl/cup as it is large and sturdy. The handle on the cup allows you to grip it securely even with wet hands. The shaving soap has a nice smell and foams up easily. Stand is about what you would expect from a entry level set like this. It is just a plain piece of acrylic plastic but it doesn't tip over and holds a razor fairly well.<br /><br />Bottom line: For the price you can't beat this set. Great for a beginner to try out or give it as a gift to someone who uses canned shaving cream.
  928. I like that they had all four pieces of this set. It comes with soap, a soap dish, the brush, and a stand for the brush to hang upside down and dry on. Also with the stand, there is a slot that allows for a razor to fit! I was buying this along with a double edge safety razor as a gift for my boyfriend and it was great I could get all of these features in one set!<br /><br />He really likes the soap and bristle feel. Eventually I might replace the brush...but this beginner's set has good bones to it!
  929. This product is pretty awesome, with one shortcoming - the brush.<br /><br />The stand is great, and holds my straight razor and the brush perfectly, just as advertised. The ceramic bowl is very solid, too - the only thing I didn't realize until I opened it up is that the bowl is much larger than it appears from the image. Not a bad thing, though, as it fits comfortably in my hand and is easy to hold to get a good lather. I'm a fan of the soap too, which does everything I expect out of a shave soap.<br /><br />My only problem is with the brush. I tried it and I really don't like it. It isn't stiff enough for me, which makes lathering and application of the soap very difficult. This may just be personal preference. All of the bristles splay out sideways upon any pressure.<br /><br />All in all, great product that has a great appearance on my bathroom counter - lost one star due to the brush not meeting my standards.<br /><br />Overall, totally worth it.
  930. Not a bad set. Just received mine a couple of days ago, but just got back from Target where I saw one for $19.99. That was their normal price. Not unhappy with the product, just feel that it is overpriced here.
  931. I bought this since I needed a stand for my new DE razor. This was a nice plastic one that looked like it wouldnt break (unlike the cheap metal ones I found online). I havnet used this shaving soap yet, and will probably only use it when I have no other choice. The brush is okay but hairs constantly fall out, it doesnt hold water or heat well. For the price, you cant beat this combo deal. Great for a wet shaver starting out. I count the days until my birthday when I can finally splurge and get a nice badger brush. The mug is really comfortable to use, but again, I dont need it and my wife thinks its junk on the counter. No regrets buying since I bought it for the stand and the brush has been working for me. Best way for a hot lather is to soak the brush in the mug with hot water while showering. Then use the cream to make a lather. Haven't been able to use the bar soap for a nice hot lather fyi. Update: 3 years later. Hairs only fell out for first month or two. I soak the mug and brush in hot water while I shower. It's about time to replace the brush. Not bad but from my above review, I didn't expect it to last this long. i use Taylor of old bond street in the tub. Put a dollop in the mug. Grab the nub with my knuckles and it's great. The mug and stand alone are worth the price. The brush more than served the price of this kit alone.
  932. The group makes a terrific starter set. I got mine about a week ago and I could not be happier. The brush has a great feel and a great lather. The shave soap that comes with can make a great lather for the price. The stand looks clean and neat and also comes in very handy.
  933. I received this set as a birthday gift and fell in love with soap shaving. It's 100 times better than gel shaving. Off the bat, I found the soap to smell really pleasant and the badger hair brush stimulates the whiskers to give a closer shave, plus it lathers the soap well.<br /><br />A few weeks later, I bought the same set on Amazon for my dad (we share the same birthday month) and he's been raving about it ever since.<br /><br />PROS:<br />-Soap shaving gives a closer shave (you can go over the same area multiple times without having to re-apply soap) and the smell is very nice.<br />-Badger hair brush helps lather and stimulate facial hair<br /><br />CONS:<br />-I don't like the mug nub to hold it. It seems awkward.<br />-Badger hair brush/razor shaver is cheaply made. But you don't need something industrial to simply hold a brush/razor<br /><br />TIPS:<br />-Replacement soap will fit in this mug. Williams makes a decent shave soap (glycerin-based) and you can skip the brush altogether and just apply soap. I'm a shower-shaver so to help cut down on space, I just apply the soap with my hands.<br /><br />All negatives aside, BUY THIS SET for a fellow shaver and they will really appreciate it.
  934. I was very impressed by the quality of this set for the price. If you're just getting into Safety Razor shaving, or picking it up again, this is a great set of accompaniment components that doesn't require a significant investment. You may graduate from the shaving soap to something that works better for your beard, but there's nothing wrong with it either. Likewise with the brush.<br /><br />Todd
  935. for those that love a clean cut and shave this will help you out more than you can imagine.. the soap leaves a clean smell as the brush lifts those tough hairs right up..and the cup does a perfect job in creating a foamy and cream moisturizing lather .. hope you all will take the time and get one .. will help you save money in the long run ...
  936. The main reason I picked up this particular set was to get this mug. I like the handle and the outwardly curving sides to allow me room to build a lather and keep it contained.<br /><br />The brush does shed a lot and I ultimately replaced it with a synthetic one that does not shed at all ([[ASIN:B0015POQ6I Beauty Strokes H.I.S Shaving Brush]]).<br /><br />The soap is hard, so it does not lather up well unless you pre-soak the soap before use. This is where the good mug comes in handy. The puck that comes with it fits nicely and it is easy to melt down future pucks (I add about 25% water first and microwave for 30 seconds) so that they fit to the edge. There is plenty of room above the soap to hold some water and build up a good cream or foam with the brush.<br /><br />I just put a little bit of hot water on top when I wake up in the morning and by the time I am done with my shower, I just take my brush (dry if badger, wet if synthetic) and swirl it around for about 40 seconds and get a nice thick lather.<br /><br />I then rinse out the brush, squeeze it dry and let it dry on the hanger. It would be nice to have a heavier hanger so that it does not tip over quite so easily, but it works.<br /><br />The reason I started looking for such a set is that I made a decision that filling my childrens' landfills with disposible cans of shaving cream was inexcusable conduct on my part. Maybe they are recycled, maybe not. Even if they are, there is a large cost to create the product. A simple bar of soap with a mug that will essentially last forever seemed a much better idea. Now that I have tried it, I even prefer it (tho I simultaneously started using baby oil as a preshave oil and that may be some of the reason I prefer it as well).
  937. I got this for my husband as a fathers day gift.<br />It's a really great value for a starter kit and quality is actually really good. My husband likes it and has now mastered the art of shaving with a straight razor.
  938. Got this kit and over all i am very happy with it. Just keep in mind that the soap provided it a bit difficult to lather for a new shaver, and the mug is a bit small for a shaving cream to mix. over all for the money, its a great set.
  939. I have been using my significant other's shaving set for the past several months. We both love this set and I finally bought a second one so we can both shave at the same time. This brush seems like it will last a long time, and as I said previously two of us were using the same brush. I like the handle on the cup for lathering the shaving soap. It is easy to hold, even with wet hands.<br /><br />We even got one of these sets to go with the safety razor we got my mom for Christmas, as she recently expressed interest in getting one.   940. The mug, stand, and brush are quite functional and a good starter set. However, I was very disappointed by the soap after I read the ingredients. Several of the ingredients listed on the box were all wonderful things, but unfortunately the 1st ingredient is propylene glycol. I don't buy anything with that in it as I believe it is poison to the skin, our largest organ. Ingredients should always be listed, as some of us pay attention to that information. I will have to find another shave soap, because I will not use this one.
  941. I got this as a gift last christmas. The stand is great, the bowl is awesome. Just throw the puck in there and make lather. The downside of this set is the brush..it sheds. I have used it for a year and I am now giving up and going synthetic. I hate having random hairs in my lather
  942. Minus the razor, this set comes with quite a bit to get you started for a shave. This set gives you the old school feel of shaving.<br /><br />The Shaving Mug/Cup/Bowl: Looks like it's porcelian made. Great quality bowl. 5/5<br /><br />Shaving Soap: The soap is actually really good. Builds up a nice lather. The scent is nice, but not overpowering. I would buy this soap again down the road if needed. Feels great on the skin. 5/5<br /><br />Brush and Razor Stand: The plastic stand does the trick. Two grooves to hold your brush and razor. Just a heads up this stand won't hold all razors so be warned. Though it's not the best looking stand, it does the job. 4/5<br /><br />Boar Brush: An ok brush. It works, but shedded a little when I started using it. It still does the job, but I see myself replacing this in the near future. I don't mind spending a little money for a better brush. 2.5/5<br /><br />Overall this is a good shave kit. Since this retails between $25-$30, it's worth a try. Good starter kit for someone interested in this style of shaving.

  951. The brush/razor holder and foam cup are the two best things about this set, and just happen to be the two main items I purchased this for. The lexan holder looks good and is perfectly functional. The cup is quality construction, looks very nice, and is easy to clean. The brush is adequate, but had a very gamey and unpleasant smell for the first few months. With some aftershave dowsing and prolonged use of fragrant shaving cream the smell eventually went away. The brush sheds about 2-3 hairs per shave. The cake soap was OK. It had a soft and pleasant smell, but not the richest lather in the world. I prefer the shave and lather from a higher quality English shave cream.<br /><br />Overall I rate this product a good value for the money. 3-stars instead of 4 due to the smell on the brush.
  952. Soap- The soap is average. Not a very strong, or easy to determine smell. Lathers up best if you lather on the face. I don't expect to use it long before upgrading.<br /><br />Stand- It's plastic. Unremarkable, but expected.<br /><br />Mug- It's a mug.   953. Great buy for the price! The mug is nice and the brush seems decent. Is it the best brush out there? No. But it's definitely a decent brush. The soap smells nice too and lathers well.<br /><br />Regarding the stand, yes as others have said it is simple, but it gets the job done. Honestly I don't know why people make such a big fuss over this. It's just something to hold you're shaving equipment while it dries, and if it really bothers you that much, then go and buy another stand with the money you saved from this purchase.<br /><br />All-in-all, this is a great value for the price.   982. I must first start with the mug. The mug is of great quality, it feels good in the hand, and there's just something about the flared mouth that makes it easier to lather.<br /><br />The soap is easy to lather. Some people are saying it won't but they don't realize that hard water has an effect on your lather. If you have hard water, try using distilled water. It's either that, or they don't put enough effort into the lather. The scent is great, too.<br /><br />The stand is nice because it has a slot to hold your straight or double edge razor.<br /><br />Now to the bad. The brush likes to shed. A lot. I suggest getting a 'Frank Shaving' brush, or the cheaper option of an 'Ecotools Bamboo Finishing Kabuki', both of which can be found on Amazon.<br /><br />The second bad thing, which isn't so much to do with the kit itself, is the price. You can find this kit at Target for just $20. Sellers on Amazon are charging $27 or more, plus shipping costs.<br /><br />Overall, it's a great kit, perfect for a beginner, except for the brush.

  991. After years of using a brush and soap from Old Spice, I found that they no longer make it.   992. If you were to go shop individually for a similar badger brush, a stand, a shaving bowl, and shaving soap, you'd easily be spending over $100. So this is a good deal for what you get.<br /><br />Here are the issues:<br /><br />- The brush: It sheds...ALOT. Seriously. Every time you lather up soap, every time you brush your face, you will find stray hairs. You can simply pull on the brush when dry and hairs will never stop shedding. I emailed the company about this, but never got a response.<br /><br />- The bowl: I'm not sure if this is a classic shaving bowl shape or not, but I don't enjoy using it. It looks cool, but if you're lathering your shaving cream, I like using more...umm...speherical containers, like a cereal bowl. This bowl is too deep and narrow. You'll be banging the sides left and right with your brush/fingers.<br /><br />The stand is pretty cool. It's honestly the only thing I still use since entering the shave-game. It holds my double-edge and/or my straight razor nicely, and my new silver-tip brush fits like a glove.<br /><br />I don't use solid shaving soap. I prefer creams instead. Never used it, so no opinion on that.<br /><br />Honestly, if you're curious about old-fashioned shaving and you're on a budget, this is a good start. IMO, shaving is one of those more zen-like experience that can really be enjoyed, appreciated, and perfected by a man with GOOD QUALITY equipment (I'm the kind of guy who likes stuff like carpentry and slow-pour coffee). If you want to just get your feet wet in shaving, try this. If you're more serious and want something long-term, look at investing in something more high-quality.
  993. Bought it for my hubby, he loves it! Saves money too!

  995. Great kit and soap for shaving with sensitive skin.
  996. I've been using this for a year and a half and am very happy with it. Thought I would offer my opinion as a long term user instead of the ones that have used it for a week.<br /><br />This review is mostly about the brush.<br /><br />I see a lot of people say that they quit using the brush after a while, but I don't see a need to do that. I shave 3-5 times a week and it is going strong.<br /><br />Are there nicer brushes out there? I'm sure there are. However, try this trick: In order to not lose this brush while traveling (about 6 weeks a year), I ended up buying a cheap boar brush from Van Der Hagen for $5. I've found if I use the boar once every 2 weeks, that in comparison this badger brush from the set feels amazingly soft after-- good enough for me, I'll use this brush until it is dead which is years away.<br /><br />My one complaint is the brush knot got loose and fell out of the handle (it was about 9 months old). Everything was still in tact. I just used Gorilla Glue to put the entire knot back in & its holding strong. (If you're confused, read up on the knots, you'll see if it is intact you're fine) I think better adhesives to hold the knot in. To me, this shouldn't have happened for at least the first 2 years. However, with the Gorilla Glue, I don't think it will happen again in 20. -- this is the reason for 4 instead of 5 stars.<br /><br />I wouldn't even include that story because I don't want to talk you out of buying this product. However, I want to give the idea if it happens to you.<br /><br />This is a starters kit, but it can also last you quite a few years if you want it to. So 5-stars if you plan to use it a year or less -- 4 stars if you want it to last 5.<br /><br />I absolutely recommend it!
  997. I'm gonna keep this short. I've used this for a while now & while the soap does seem to take a little longer to lather than the other one I used it produces a good shave. I will say if you're looking to buy this I paid about $10 LESS at a major retail store that has &#34;everyday low prices.&#34;
  998. I gave this shave set 1 start because the the Brush broker after one month of normal use. By ''broker'' I mean the entire BRISTLE part of the brush came a part from the Handle. It was just glued on to the handle and must of been a very low quality glue! And YES I did gently rinsed it and hung it to dry after every use.   999. I have recently started shaving with a safety razor and heard that if you want to do it right, you need to buy a badger brush. So I looked into it and found this shave set. Here's the breakdown of what I've learned after using each item in the set.<br /><br />The Brush: Overall its a great brush. Its made of actual badger hair and does not shed very much at all. The quality of the brush actually surprised me.<br /><br />The Bowl: What can I say? Its a bowl. It contains the soap while you lather. However I will note that the handle is nice when you have wet slippery hands.<br /><br />The Soap: Smells great, and does not require too much effort to lather into a nice creamy texture. Also feels great when you apply it to your face and gives protection during your shave.<br /><br />The Stand: Made of a heavy plastic. Does its job and holds the brush and my safety razor. I have had no issue with the stand tipping over.<br /><br />Conclusion: Buy it. What I've found is that you can purchase this quality set for the cost of a brush alone, and its worth it. Great as a gift for someone else or you can purchase it for yourself.

  1013. First impression: packaging is nicely done, the whole thing is in a nice box with plenty of quality foam padding and in todays world where some companies put a lot of thought into how their items present at unboxing I was impressed. The mug feels solid and substantial, soap smells mild but pleasant, the brush is very soft right out of the box. Plastic stand but it looks nice and holds the brush as shown in the picture.<br />Second impression: everything was great with the set, quality was good with one exception, the brush smells very bad when it gets wet. I can't place the smell but it makes me think of musty-burnt hair. I have washed the brush with shampoo twice, the smell is getting better and I will wash it a few more times before using it again. Some info I found online recommends soaking the brush for a couple minutes in a diluted vinegar & warm water mix to knock down the smell - I hope that works well as the smell is very strong and sticks with your nose long after the shave. The stand is too short for a standard cartridge razor (fusion or mach3, etc) but works well with a short DE unit.<br />IF the brush smell issue gets corrected with a good soaking I will be very happy with this set.<br /><br />Update: soaked the brush for 2 minutes in vinegar and hot water, rinsed it out, dried it a bit more by brushing it against a dry towel and the smell was much better this morning. It did lose a few more hairs this morning (about as many as I lose each day) but over time the brush should lose fewer and fewer (wish I could say the same for me). Happy shaving.

  1057. I own about a dozen brushes, from vintage nylon-bristle brushes to modern badgers. I've also used bunches of shaving soaps and creams.<br /><br />The Van Der Hagen shaving soap is quite good, especially for the price. The bowl is also perfectly functional and attractive. The weakness is the pure-badger shaving brush. It doesn't have much backbone, and it consequently doesn't work well for lathering up a hard soap such as the one supplied with the kit. It works better on shaving creams. I just used it with C.O. Bigelow shaving cream (manufactured by Proraso), and the brush worked fine. It did shed bristles, but new badgers will do so.<br /><br />With that said, I've used the Van Der Hagen bowl and soap with stiffer brushes, including nylon, boar, and badger brushes, and it's very good. Just pick up a good Omega or Semogue boar-bristle brush (they can be found at very reasonable prices), and you'll be good to go. After you use the products for a year or so, you'll have paid for them because of the reduced cost compared to aerosol foams or gels.

  1061. Had been using an electric shaver for years after making the switch from expensive multi blade cartridges. Through the years, I can't say that I was every truly happy with the closeness or experience of dry shaving. After thinking about going back to wet shaving, I stumbled into the recent movement of guys going back to DE Safety razors.<br /><br />I was a bit intimidated at using this today, when it came in the mail, since I had never used a safety razor before. I ordered it with the Edwin Jagger DE89Lbl Lined Detail Chrome Plated Double Edge Safety Razor and took it for a test drive. I was surprised at how little effort it took for me to get a good shave. it did help to get some examples from Youtube on proper lathering and shaving techniques. But wow, what an experience! The razor doesn't take that much effort to use. You let its weight, angle, and the blade do the work. The shaving soap is much better than anything out of a can, and smells great!. I did three passes: down, ear to nose, and up against the grain. I didn't get one nick on my face! I'm a medium thickness beard kind of guy, and this shaving soap was perfect for me. I have ordered and will be trying the Men's Soap Company Shaving Soap next to get some different varieties in. The stand is straight forward, and I have noticed some badger hairs coming off the brush in my first use, but the brush itself feels comfortable, and I appreciate the price for a starter kit for someone like myself who wasn't sure if they would like DE Safety Razor Shaving. The experience has been great for me, and I will be upgrading the badger brush in the future, and possible the razor/brush stand in the future. The apothecary mug is great and does what it's supposed to. I would recommend getting another small bowl to work your lather and load your brush separately. Anything at home that you can use for this purpose will suffice, i.e. small ceramic kitchen bowl or cereal bowl should do the trick.

  1068. I'll preface this review with saying that I'm a huge fan of \\"old school\\" shaving with the DE razors brush and cream. I've tried everything from electric, Mach 3 - fusion, cheap disposables just about everything and nothing has given me a closer more comfortable shave than a DE with a good quality blade, brush, and cream. The quality of this set is \\"serviceable\\" and nothing beyond that.<br /><br />I've seen a lot of reviews that say this is great for beginners but in my opinion a cheap set is the last thing a beginner should be getting that's a great way to end up back spending big $ on fusion cartridges or hacking your face up. If you're thinking about making the switch spend your $30 on a tub of Taylor of old bond street cream (one tub will last over 6 months if used properly and doesn't require a bowl) and a decent brush (tweezerman has a decent $10 brush)

  1076. I tried going to brush shaving a couple of years ago. To start out with, I bought a Burma-Shave synthetic brush and Williams shaving soap from Walmart and was underwhelmed. I could get lather, but only after a long time, and not the quality of lather I wanted either.<br /><br />I got a double edge handle and blades here on Amazon ([[ASIN:B003YJ70NY Feather Double-Edge Razor by Jatai comes with 2 Hi-Stainless Blades]]) and decided I'd have to get something better, preferably a badger brush. I've seen that green set going around Rite-Aid and Amazon, but reviews on YouTube have given it a mediocre rating at best. This set has gotten better reviews so I though I could give it a try.<br /><br />First of all, the brush is very well made for what it is. It has a metal ferrule and no smell (they probably treat it or wash it prior to packing, good move). There was no loss of hairs and it held the water very well. Lathering was no problem, if anything, it made too much. The soap is nice, not overly fragrant, the cup is beautiful and the lexan razor/brush stand helps in keeping you organized. On this one, you're paying for the brush and get the other stuff thrown in as a bonus. I'm very satisfied
  1077. These items arrived before the time and I am very please with them. I learned to shave using a shaving cup and soap. I went back to them because of the cost of always buying shaving soap and blades.<br />I would recommend these items. But be ready to relearn how to shave again.
  1078. OK so it's not that powerful, but I do feel manly after shaving with this set.<br /><br />The soap suds up very well with my badger hair brush, but does not leave a film on my face when done. It has a great scent that's not too overpowering. This set was well worth the money.
  1079. I would not recommend this to anyone. The only value you'll get from this is the bowl and soap. The brush broke (gentle use) within the first two weeks, and the stand is plastic. Buy the bowl and soap separately and save your money for something better.
  1080. I like this set. The soap and mug are very nice, and the badger brush works well too. My main concern is that the hair on the brush are coming out more and more. I feel like it's probably time to buy a higher quality brush. I would still recommend getting this set if your not sure if you want to shave with a brush and soap (or shave cream). It's a good set to find out if you like it before you spend too much on something else.
  1081. Lets start with the best part of this set, the soap mug. It is a nice peice, with a good weight, comfy handle and a handsome appearance. The soap that goes in the mug is nice as well. It has a pleasant aroma and can be made to produce a decent lather. The brush is where this set isn't that great. The brissles refuse to stop falling out, and it only does a mediocre job of lathering. It's decent for a first brush and lets you get use to that badger funk. The stand is cheap looking and is really more of an added bonus than it is a focus peice. It does let the brush dry correctly though so I can't fault it much. All in all for the money its a nice set and will get you on your way to wet shaving.
  1082. I bought this for my father and he is very pleased with the shave set! The Brush bristles are very soft and the soap works well!
  1083. Ordered this as part of a homemade gift set for my boyfriend's birthday. The brush is really nice, even softer than ones we looked at together in a fancy upscale shaving store. The soap does not irritate his somewhat sensitive skin, now does it dry his skin out.   1085. The mug is great. The brush is ok. And the soap is well, I guess some people might like it.<br />I love the mug. It looks nice on the counter, and it's easy enough to work with.<br />The brush has its moments, but my brush loses at least one bristle every time I use it to lather and apply. It's pretty nice going on, until you have a badger bristle stuck to your face.<br />The soap works well enough, but I was expecting something that smelled a little more manly, like a cologne at best, or at least like a can of shave foam. Negative. It's more sweaty flowers than old spice. The good news is soap is available at some grocery stores.<br />So you're probably not going to be blown away, but you'll be satisfied if you snag this on your way to transforming shaving from a daily chore to a relaxing ritual.<br />And lastly,my tip for getting a good lather: patience. If its your first time you're going to go at that soap for a minute or two and think you're done, but all you're going to have is a watery mess. Keep going my good man! You'll be able to turn that soap into a rich foam - like a modern day alchemist - with just a little more effort and time
  1086. The badger brush is good quality and I haven't had any issues with hairs shedding. Soap and mug are just ok. I get a lot more lather using a more conventional shaped bowl. The clear stand works well and has a spot to hang you razor in the back.
  1087. I liked the shave set, but, there were a lot of loose hairs in the brush, everything else was good.
  1088. This is a GREAT starter shave set. I have extremely sensitive skin but very light hair growth and have always struggled getting a quality shave. I've tried every fancy razor, disposable and after spending loads of money decided to give wet shaving with a double edged razor a try. Not wanting to waste a lot of money I scoured the internet for what would be the best value and quality for a beginner. I settled on this set as it came with everything I wanted (mug, stand, brush and soap) and a Weishi razor (also from here on Amazon). So for $35 I got started. I LOVE IT! The mug is perfectly shaped for the soap pucks. The soap lathers easily once you get the hang of it. Less water at first gives a better lather, as does lathering in a separate bowl. I use this mug only to hold the puck and load the brush. I actually love the soap so much that I buy it from a local store and use it as my shower bar as well. I can't describe the smell but it is GREAT! The brush is soft and had little smell when I got it. My only complaint is it has shed a few hairs but that's about it. The stand holds the brush well and has a cut out for a razor as well, though the razors I have don't want to set too well and can easily be knocked out so I use a different stand for the razor. I am 100% satisfied in this purchase and got everything I wanted and they were quality items. Don't hesitate to buy if you're a beginner. This along with a decent razor and blades will give you the confidence to wet shave! Can't recommend it more!
  1089. I used to hate shaving, but now it's a least more fun and different.
  1090. Only downside it that the brush is constantly shedding. Otherwise I would have given a 5.

  1093. This was my starting shave set and it works as advertised. Doing further research the stand for the brush is unneeded and because it is light plastic a little awkward to use. Brush, Bowl, and Soap are all excellent starter pieces
  1094. I am new to safety razor shaving and I purchased this set to use with a new Merkur 33C safety razor.<br /><br />Initially looking the set over when it arrived I noticed that with the exception of the shaving soap, the rest of the set is made in China. Here are my thoughts on the rest of the set:<br /><br />Shaving Mug - Good heavy duty shaving mug. Quality seems to be decent.<br /><br />Brush/Razor Stand - Kind of cheap feeling acrylic or plastic of some sort. It is nice to have the stand to allow the brush to dry in an inverted position and to have a place to store your razor. However the razor slot doesn't exactly hold the razor securely. It sits in there ok, but it isn't the most secure. Just don't bump it or your razor might fall out.<br /><br />Brush - Molded plastic handle with logo. Feels ok in your hand. Would probably be nice if it were a little heavier weight. I have been shaving with it for a few weeks and have had some bristle loss. About 8-10 the first time I used it and I lose a few every time I use it. Not really a big deal in my opinion. The bristles are quite soft, but I only have a cheap boar brush to compare it to.<br /><br />Soap - Soap seems ok and has a nice scent. Not sure if it is my technique or my hard water at home, but I never seem to be able to work up enough quality lather. I leave the soap in the plastic container, load the brush tips for a minute and work into a lather in the shave mug. I always seem to need to go back to reload the brush at least a second or third time. Otherwise the lather is too thin and disappears half way through the shave (on my face).<br /><br />For the price I think it is a good set. Buying a cheap mug, brush/razor stand, brush and soap idividually would cost way more than the $32 that I paid for this set. I think it is a good starting point to get into safety razor shaving. Try it out and then purchase better quality things when you figure out exactly what you want.
  1095. The mug is the best part of this set. The brush is just ok it is a little stiff handle i good. The stand is cheap but it works for now. The soap smells ok but not the best. And it is hard to get a great lather from it.

I ended up purchasing a separate lather that I am very happy with and is much easier to use and am keeping the lather they gave as back-up in case I can't get some more lather for a period when I run out.<br /><br />For the price and to just start out, I think it is a great little pack. Everything is decent quality, and even if you use a cartridge razor, I would very much recommend using a brush and lather for your shave. The only thing I caution is that you may need to get some added lather, but of course that is your choice.

  1121. The mug is great. I love the soap too. It lathers nice with a masculine scent. The lather is rich and not too dense. Provides a decent cushion and an ok glide. I was expecting some shedding like on my tweezerman and escali beginner badger brushes but this thing sheds way too much. I prepped it beforehand like all my badger and boar brushes but the Vander Hagen brush is terrible. It dyes the water when I soak it and it dries way too fast when I attempt a face lather. Badger brush claim to fame is the water and heat retention. This brush does none of those things. Not made for soap shaving. Cream only on this thing. I gave it 6 attempts. For break in. But it only gets worse. The only redeeming quality on the brush is the nice shiny black handle and the Van Der Hagen logo. This brush alone can put off beginner DE safety razor folks. I can't recommend this product. I ordered another set to see if it was just some random QC issue with the brush. It's a great price for the set. So I will give it another chance.

  1147. This is an OK way to start wet shaving if you have no idea what you are doing. It's not the best kit and you can get a lot better stuff for around the same price. The cup is good and the stand is OK. I really hate the brush out of this kit though. It's very scratchy and sheds hairs. I would change out the brush ASAP. If you want a cheap brush, I recommend you replace the brush with something else like: Omega Shaving Brush #10048 (chrome) or #10049 (black) Very large boar brush with a huge knot, 28mm knot. Unclipped and will get softer with time. Omega Shaving Brush #20102 Large boar brush with a 27mm knot. Unclipped and will get softer with time. Very comfortable handle. Omega Shaving Brush #10065 (many colors to choose from) or #10066 (faux ivory) Medium size boar brush, 24mm knot. Unclipped hairs that get softer with time. Omega S-Brush #S10065 (many colors to choose from) or #S10019 (black and clear) Medium size synthetic brush, 24mm knot. Not made from animal hair and thus very low maintenance. No break in required. Good firm feel but still very soft tips. Vie-Long #12705 Medium size horse hair brush, 23mm knot. Horse hair is fairly soft. No break in required. Semogue #1470 (wood handle) or #1460 (painted wood handle) Small size boar brush, 21mm knot. Nice feel of the wood handle. The hairs are also unclipped and will get softer with time. Notice I didn't recommend any badger brushes? This is because there are virtually no good badger brushes in the $10-$20 price range. Good badger brushes start at around $30. Most good cheap brushes will be bore hair, horse hair, or synthetic.
  1148. Overall this is a pretty good deal. I'm happy with the overall value and it's got me shaving but there are some good and bad.<br /><br />The good.<br />The plastic holder is a non-issue. The stand is good, clear quality plastic that will fit in with pretty much any decor.
  1160. I wasn't sure I would like adding the time neccessary for lathering the soap but, the shave is worth it and the process takes maybe 30 seconds. The brush sheds. I have used it 12-20 times and it is still losing hair. I use a single blade disposable and get a great shave. I have fine whiskers not heavy. 6-5-13 The brushed stopped shedding. I use canned soap only when traveling and miss this system when I do. Infact, I purchased a premium razor that accepts three blade cartridges. I do believe both have spoiled me. I really do recommend it. 2-13-15 still no shedding and the brush works well
  1161. The brush fell apart pretty quickly.
  1162. This set is beautiful! The stand, the brush, and the mug that came with it was all packaged nicely and securely in the box. The soap that came with it smells nice and the mug feels really good in your hand, it has some weight to it and looks amazing. The brush is badger hair which I heard was a must have for shaving. Overall great set, totally worth the money.
  1163. It's a great, quality set. Works well for my needs, but the badger hair brush 'sheds' a bit more than I would like. Otherwise a great quality overall.
  1164. This stuff lathers up really good and fast. Feels really nice on the face. The brush is losing some bristles but I would expect that from any brush. Its not falling apart or losing so many where I cannot use it but some are coming off.
  1165. My husband had never used a straight edge razor so we needed to buy everything. I really love the smell of the soap that comes with this set, and the brush has yet to fall apart so that's always a good thing! I wish he had a way to store his razor in the stand since I believe this is made for a safety razor, but that's not anyone's problem but ours :)
  1166. Overall I did enjoy this set. The bowl and stand where the two main reasons I purchased this set since it was difficult to find a stand that held both the brush and razor. Any stand I found was $15-$20 for the stand alone. An additional $12 for the bowl, brush and soap made this the best deal.<br /><br />My main issue is with the brush quality. Not with the quality of the badger hair since that seems to be of a high quality, but, with the glue used to hold the hair into the handle. The brush hair and handle glue contact area is very small and after a little more than 3 months of use the brush handle and the brush hair came apart. I now no longer have a brush that I can use but I will be looking into the Tweezerman as a replacement soon.<br /><br />Overall, if you want a cheap entry level set, buy this, but be prepared to buy a new brush soon.
  1167. First I had hair on my face, but now I do not! Far superior to disposable razors.
  1168. Just recently switched to shaving with a d.e. safety razor. While looking for the necessary supplies I came across this set. In deciding between buying everything separately for up to two or three times more than the cost of this, it was simply a no-brainer. While the quality of the brush itself is not necessarily on par with other badger brushes, it still gets the job done. Love this set.
  1169. Pretty good bang for the buck here.<br /><br />The soap produces a slick creamy lather and has a pleasant aroma. It's very lightly scented which I appreciate. I'm not a fan of heavily perfumed products, I don't enjoy smelling like the urinal in a Portuguese cat-house so the soap is a winner for me.<br /><br />The mug is high quality. It holds the soap puck perfectly and it looks really nice on the bathroom counter. It's sturdy and heavy duty but not so much that it's uncomfortable to hold while loading the brush.<br /><br />The stand is clear acrylic. Not top shelf but you're not paying for top shelf with this package. It's sturdy enough that it won't tip over and it's clear so it doesn't stand out, it just does it's job. I could see upgrading to a nicer stand in the future but for now this one is just fine.<br /><br />The main drawback of this kit is the brush. It's not all that bad, it just sheds a lot. I don't have a problem working up a decent lather with it and it feels good enough on my face but it's kind of a pain picking little badger hairs out of the soap puck to keep the aforementioned good counter looks up to snuff. Of all the things in this kit the brush is the first thing I'm going to replace. I'm not in a huge rush though, it works well enough.<br /><br />I'd recommend this kit to people getting into the wonderful world of wet shaving but it's not like you're set for life with this stuff. After getting the basics down you'll start longing for higher quality gear but don't let that sway you from using this to get your foot in the door.
  1170. he love this, and it arrived in a timely manner.
  1171. I purchased a set for myself about a year ago and have been very pleased with the quality of the brush, soap, and mug. Purchased the same set as a gift for my dad and he likes it as well. I feel that my skin is far less irritated when using this in lieu of a gel or cream.
  1172. Aesthetically, I like it. The cup looks very nice, it is easy to hold (not sure what people are taking about....). The stand is a cheapy, clear acrylic-- but it doesn't look awful and serves its purpose. The soap is nice and works. My biggest issue is the brush. Extremely low quality, the bristles fall out from the first use. Bristles all in the soap cup, on my face, and in my sink when rinsing it off. The brush ruins this set. If you already own a brush, the set does look nice and may be worth getting.
  1173. This is my first wet shave kit, so I am no expert, but I know quality when I see it, and I see it here. I have used this product for over six months now, at least three times a week consistently, and I have been pleased every time, not once returning to the pressurized foam or gel.<br /><br />First, the plastic stand. It is strong. It works. I have dropped it on the floor numerous times, and it will not break. Its not pretty, but if thats what you want, you are barking up the wrong the tree.<br /><br />Second, the mug. It is hefty and sturdy. The volume is sufficient. I have never dropped this thing, but it is ceramic, so it might break. Be careful about that. If you a clutz, plastic might be the way to go.<br /><br />Third, the soap. It was nice and lasted about three months. Not bad, not bad at all, considering a can of the goop costs at least $2. I replaced it with some generic soap I found at CVS, and it was less than $1. This is the economic way to go.<br /><br />Fourth, last and most important, the brush. I love it. It is smooth and gets a good lather. It exfoliates the skin just fine. The handle does its job. Up to this point, about 50 or so hairs have fallen out. Out of the thousands that are one there, that is nothing. It feels just as full as it did the first day, and I believe it is full enough.<br /><br />Overall, great product. Probably no need to spend any more on this type of product than necessary. In my opinion, one of the key points to the wet shave is economy.
